news_summary: A groundbreaking fossil find in Ethiopia is reshaping our understanding of human origins.
news_summary_fr: La découverte d'un fossile en Éthiopie bouleverse notre compréhension des origines de l'homme.
news_summary_es: Un hallazgo fósil pionero en Etiopía está redefiniendo nuestra comprensión de los orígenes humanos.

articles.title: Ancient fossil discovery in Ethiopia rewrites human origins
articles.summary: In the deserts of Ethiopia, scientists uncovered fossils showing that early members of our genus Homo lived side by side with a newly identified species of Australopithecus nearly three million years ago. These finds challenge the old idea of a straight evolutionary ladder, revealing instead a tangled web of ancient relatives.
articles.content:
A team of international scientists has discovered new fossils at a field site in Africa that indicate Australopithecus, and the oldest specimens of Homo, coexisted at the same place in Africa at the same time -- between 2.6 and 2.8 million years ago. The paleoanthropologists discovered a new species of Australopithecus that has never been found anywhere.

The Ledi-Geraru Research Project is led by scientists at Arizona State University and the site has revealed the oldest member of the genus Homo and the earliest Oldowan stone tools on the planet.

The research team concluded that the Ledi-Geraru Australopithecus teeth are a new species, rather than belonging to Australopithecus afarensis (the famous 'Lucy'), confirming that there is still no evidence of Lucy's kind younger than 2.95 million years ago.

"This new research shows that the image many of us have in our minds of an ape to a Neanderthal to a modern human is not correct -- evolution doesn't work like that," said ASU paleoecologist Kaye Reed. "Here we have two hominin species that are together. And human evolution is not linear, it's a bushy tree, there are life forms that go extinct."

Reed is a Research Scientist at the Institute of Human Origins and President's Professor Emerita at the School of Human Evolution and Social Change at ASU. She has been co-director of the Ledi-Geraru Research Project since 2002.

Ledi-Geraru

What fossils did they find to help them tell this story? Teeth, 13 of them to be exact.

This field site has been famous before. In 2013 a team led by Reed discovered the jaw of the earliest Homo specimen ever found at 2.8 million years old. This new paper details new teeth found at the site that belong to both the genus Homo and a new species of the genus Australopithecus.

"The new finds of Homo teeth from 2.6 - 2.8 million year old sediments -- reported in this paper -- confirms the antiquity of our lineage," said Brian Villmoare, lead author and ASU alumnus.

"We know what the teeth and mandible of the earliest Homo look like, but that's it. This emphasizes the critical importance of finding additional fossils to understand the differences

between Australopithecus and Homo, and potentially how they were able to overlap in the fossil record at the same location."

The team cannot name the species yet based on the teeth alone; more fossils are needed before that can happen.

How old are the fossils?

How do scientists know these fossil teeth are millions of years old?

Volcanoes.

The Afar region is still an active rifting environment. There were a lot of volcanoes and tectonic activity and when these volcanoes erupted ash, the ash contained crystals called feldspars that allow the scientists to date them, explained Christopher Campisano, a geologist at ASU.

"We can date the eruptions that were happening on the landscape when they're deposited," said Campisano, a Research Scientist at the Institute of Human Origins and Associate Professor at the School of Human Evolution and Social Change.

"And we know that these fossils are interbed between those eruptions, so we can date units above and below the fossils. We are dating the volcanic ash of the eruptions that were happening while they were on the landscape."

Finding fossils and dating the landscape not only helps scientists understand the species - it helps them recreate the environment millions of years ago. The modern faulted badlands of Ledi-Geraru, where the fossils were found are a stark contrast to the landscape these hominins traversed 2.6 - 2.8 million years ago. Back then, rivers migrated across a vegetated landscape into shallow lakes that expanded and contracted over time.

Ramon Arrowsmith, a geologist at ASU, has been working with the Ledi-Geraru Research Project since 2002. He explained the area has an interpretable geologic record with good age control for the geologic time range of 2.3 to 2.95 million years ago.

"It is a critical time period for human evolution as this new paper shows," said Arrowsmith, professor at the School of Earth and Space Exploration. "The geology gives us the age and characteristics of the sedimentary deposits containing the fossils. It is essential for age control."

What's next?

Reed said the team is examining tooth enamel now to find out what they can about what these species were eating. There are still remaining questions the team will continue to work on.

Were the early Homo and this unidentified species of Australopithecus eating the same things? Were they fighting for or sharing resources? Did they pass each other daily? Who were the ancestors of these species?

No one knows - yet.

"Whenever you have an exciting discovery, if you're a paleontologist, you always know that you need more information," said Reed. "You need more fossils. That's why it's an important field to train people in and for people to go out and find their own sites and find places that we haven't found fossils yet."

"More fossils will help us tell the story of what happened to our ancestors a long time ago -- but because we're the survivors we know that it happened to us."

The paper "New discoveries of Australopithecus and Homo from Ledi-Geraru, Ethiopia," was published in the journal Nature. The team of scientists and field team working on this project is widespread and many work at Arizona State University, or are alumni of ASU.

ASU alumni and current faculty authors include; Associate Professor Brian Villmoare, Associate Professor Lucas Delezene, Professor Amy Rector, Associate Research Professor Erin DiMaggio, Research Professor David Feary, PhD Candidate Daniel Chupik, Instructor Dominique Garello, Assistant Professor Ellis M. Locke, Lecturer Joshua Robinson, Assistant Professor Irene Smail and the late Professor William Kimbel.

This finding challenges previous linear models of human ancestry, providing a more complex and accurate picture of human origins with broad implications for science and education. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights ongoing research and future questions, demonstrating substantial real-world impact in the field of paleoanthropology.
articles.personality_title: New fossil discovery shows early humans lived alongside another ancient species
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long studied how humans evolved from earlier species. For many years, they thought human evolution was a simple, straight line from ape-like ancestors to modern humans.

**What happened** – In Ethiopia, researchers found fossils of teeth from nearly three million years ago. These teeth belong to two different groups: early humans (genus Homo) and a newly discovered species of Australopithecus, a type of ancient human relative. The fossils were found at the Ledi-Geraru site, where earlier discoveries included the oldest known Homo jaw and stone tools. Scientists dated the fossils using volcanic ash layers nearby.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that early humans and another ancient species lived at the same time in the same place. It challenges the old idea that human evolution was a simple, straight path. Instead, it looks more like a bushy tree with many branches. This helps us understand that our family tree is more complex than we thought and that different human relatives may have interacted or competed.

**What's next step** – The research team is now studying the teeth to learn what these species ate and how they lived together. They want to find more fossils to better understand how these species were related and how they shared their environment. More discoveries could reveal new details about our early ancestors.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Fossils from Ethiopia show that early humans and a new ancient species lived side by side nearly three million years ago, revealing a more complex human family tree than previously believed.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle découverte fossile révèle que les premiers humains coexistaient avec une autre espèce ancienne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques ont longtemps étudié comment les humains ont évolué à partir d'espèces plus anciennes. Pendant des années, ils pensaient que l'évolution humaine suivait une ligne droite simple, allant des ancêtres ressemblant à des singes jusqu'aux humains modernes.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – En Éthiopie, des chercheurs ont découvert des fossiles de dents datant d'il y a près de trois millions d'années. Ces dents appartiennent à deux groupes différents : les premiers humains (genre Homo) et une nouvelle espèce d'Australopithèque, un type de parent ancien des humains. Les fossiles ont été trouvés sur le site de Ledi-Geraru, où des découvertes antérieures comprenaient la plus vieille mâchoire Homo connue et des outils en pierre. Les scientifiques ont daté les fossiles grâce à des couches de cendres volcaniques proches.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que les premiers humains et une autre espèce ancienne vivaient en même temps au même endroit. Cela remet en question l'idée ancienne d'une évolution humaine simple et linéaire. Au lieu de cela, l'évolution ressemble plutôt à un arbre touffu avec plusieurs branches. Cela nous aide à comprendre que notre arbre généalogique est plus complexe que ce que l'on pensait et que différents parents humains ont peut-être interagi ou rivalisé.

**Prochaine étape** – L'équipe de recherche étudie maintenant les dents pour savoir ce que ces espèces mangeaient et comment elles vivaient ensemble. Ils veulent trouver plus de fossiles pour mieux comprendre les liens entre ces espèces et comment elles partageaient leur environnement. De nouvelles découvertes pourraient révéler plus de détails sur nos ancêtres anciens.

**Phrase clé** – Des fossiles d'Éthiopie montrent que les premiers humains et une nouvelle espèce ancienne vivaient côte à côte il y a près de trois millions d'années, révélant un arbre généalogique humain plus complexe que ce que l'on croyait.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo hallazgo fósil muestra que los primeros humanos convivieron con otra especie antigua
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han estudiado durante mucho tiempo cómo evolucionaron los humanos a partir de especies anteriores. Durante años, pensaron que la evolución humana era una línea recta simple desde ancestros parecidos a monos hasta humanos modernos.

**Qué pasó** – En Etiopía, investigadores encontraron fósiles de dientes de hace casi tres millones de años. Estos dientes pertenecen a dos grupos diferentes: los primeros humanos (género Homo) y una nueva especie descubierta de Australopithecus, un tipo de pariente antiguo de los humanos. Los fósiles se hallaron en el sitio Ledi-Geraru, donde antes se encontraron la mandíbula más antigua de Homo y herramientas de piedra. Los científicos dataron los fósiles usando capas de ceniza volcánica cercanas.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento muestra que los primeros humanos y otra especie antigua vivieron al mismo tiempo y lugar. Esto desafía la idea antigua de que la evolución humana fue un camino simple y lineal. En cambio, parece un árbol con muchas ramas. Esto ayuda a entender que nuestro árbol familiar es más complicado de lo que se pensaba y que diferentes parientes humanos pudieron haber interactuado o competido.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de investigación está estudiando los dientes para saber qué comían estas especies y cómo vivían juntas. Quieren encontrar más fósiles para entender mejor cómo se relacionaban estas especies y cómo compartían su ambiente. Nuevos descubrimientos podrían mostrar más detalles sobre nuestros primeros antepasados.

**Frase clave** – Fósiles de Etiopía muestran que los primeros humanos y una nueva especie antigua vivieron juntos hace casi tres millones de años, revelando un árbol familiar humano más complejo de lo que se creía.
